fields: Defined as the common denominator between people.
Philosophical foundation
What are the root words of "philosophy"
Philo + Sophia
What do philo and sophia mean respectively?
love & wisdom
What is the first step to attain wisdom?
Emtpy your mind
Why is philosophy considered a science?
It is similar to the scientific method in some aspects.
Why is philosophy considered the natural light of reason?
Because it guides, and we ONLY use human reason for it. Which identity of philosophy is this?
Why is philosophy considered the study of all things?
Because philosophers have no specialty. Extremely broad. Which identity of philosophy is this?
Which definition of philosophy contains the different principles?
The first cause or highest principle contains what?
Enumerate the 3 components of the Principle of Identity

- Whatever is is
- Whatever is not is not
- Everything is what it is

Which principle contains these?
What does the principle of non-contradiction state?
It is impossible for something to be and not to be at the same time. Which principle is this>
The principle of excluded middle states that?
A thing either is or not. No grey area. Which principle is this?
The principle of sufficient reason states that?
Nothing exists without a reason. Which principle states this?
Defined as genuine understanding of all the most diverse points of view.
Holistic perspective
A narrow provincialism of the mind, limited to ideas and outlook
Partial Perspective

the branch of philosophy that studies the nature
of reality, existence, and what it means for something to "be.
Metaphysics
It explains which part of our experience we call unreal in terms of what we call real.
Metaphysics
This metaphysician said reality is water
Thales of Miletus
Why did Thales believe reality is water
Because water is the source of all being
This metaphysician is not  known for getting the answer  right but gave birth to the question "What is everything really made of?"
Thales
Which metaphysician said that reality is air
Anaximenes
Why does anaximenes believe reality is air?
Just as our breath animates us, air animates the universe
Who said that reality is fire?
Heraclitus
Why did heraclitus say reality is fire?

Fire represents the essential nature of the universe: ever-
changing, dynamic, and governed by a rational order (Logos).
Who said that reality is made of the 4 elements?
Empedocles

Empedocles believed that the elements of reality are combined
and separated by the opposing forces of {{c1::Love}} and {{c1::Chaos}}.
Who said that reality comes from the apeiron?
Anaximander
Whose metaphysics defines the ultimate reality as a thing we can neither touch nor see
Anaximander
The apeiron is defined as what?
indefinite, eternal, unlimited substance
Who said that reality can only be detected by the intellect
Plato
Plato's metaphysics is also known as?
The theory of forms

Plato believes that only through {{c1::rational thought (not senses)}} can
we gain true knowledge of what really exists.
Known as the study of knowledge
epistemology
What are the 3 questions epistemology explains?

1. How we know what we claim to know
2. How to know what we wish to know
3. How we can differentiate truth from falsehood

A theory of epistemology described as the real knowledge that is based
on what our senses tell us is really out there
Empiricism
This theory of epistemology describes real knowledge as based on logic, the laws, and the methods that reason develops
Rationalism
This theory of epistemology says that knowledge is constructed by the mind based on experience
Constructivism
This theory of epistemology states that we can't be sure of anything, knowledge is uncertain
Skepticism
This theory of epistemology states that truth is what works in practice, knowledge is based on utility
Pragmatism
What are the 2 types of reasoning in epistemology?
Deductive and Inductive
Which type of reasoning is broad -> specific?
deductive reasoning
which type of reasoning is specific -> broad?
inductive reasoning
Defined as the study of valid reasoning
Logic
Where does the word "logic" come from, and what does that root word mean
Greek word “Logike” meaning treatise pertaining to the human thought.
Logic is not interested in what we know, but what?
the validity of our arguments
What are the 5 elements of logical reasoning

1. Premise
2. Conclusion
3. Argument
4. Validity
5. Soundness
This element of logical reasoning is defined as a statement assumed to be true and used to support a conclusion
Premise
This element of logical reasoning is defined as a statement that follows logically from the premises
Conclusion
This element of logical reasoning is defined as a group of statements structured to support a claim
Argument
What are the two components of arguments?
premises and conclusion
An argument is valid when?
if the conclusion logicall follows the premises
An argument is sound when?
If it is valid and the premises are true

Attacking the person instead of the argument

"You can’t trust anything Sarah says about climate change. She’s just a
crazy environmentalist."
Ad Hominem

is the distortion of someone else’s argument to make it
easier to attack
Straw man

Presenting only two extreme options, excluding others.

"You’re either with us or against us."
False Dilemma

Assuming one small step will lead to extreme outcomes

"If we allow phones in class, next we’ll cancel school!"
Slippery slope

A claim is true because many people do it

“Everyone is buying iPhone. So, it must be the best phone.
Bandwagon

introducing an irrelevant topic to divert attention.

“You asked me why I missed the deadline, but let’s talk about how busy I am
working on other projects."
Red herring

drawing a conclusion based on insufficient evidence

“I met a rude person in Nabunturan, so everyone in that place must be rude."
Hasty generalization
What are the two branches of axiology?
Ethics and Aesthetics
Defined as the study of moral values?
ethics
This branch of philosophy explores how humans should act, why we should act that way, and what it means to live a good and meaningful life.
Ethics
According to ethics, is knowledge theoretical or practical?
practical, we should not only know the rules but live with it.

Whose philosophy is this:

A person has to live a virtuous life
Socrates

According to {{c2::plato}}, the values that constitute a human person are:
{{c1::courage, hope, and love.}}
What are aristotle's 2 main philosophies?
Eudaimonia and Teleology
This philosophy states that happiness is the goal of life
Eudaimonia
This philosophy states that everything has a natural goal or purpose
Teleology
This philosophy is also known as ethical hedonism
Epicureanism
Whose philosophy is epicureanism?
Epicurus
This philosophy states that pleasure is the highest good
Epicureanism

Who made this contribution to ethics?:

- Christian ethics
St. Augustine

Who made this contribution to ethics?:

- Natural law theory
St. Thomas Aquinas

Who made this contribution to ethics?:

- Influenced liberalism
John locke

Who made this contribution to ethics?:

- Ethics is based on emotion
David Hume

Who made this contribution to ethics?:

- Deontology
Immanuel kant
An ethical theory that states actions are good or bad according to a clear set of rules
Deontology

Who made this contribution to ethics?:

- Ethics and freedom
Jean-Jacques Rousseau

Who made this contribution to ethics?:

- Utilitarianism/Consequentialism
Jeremy Bentham

Who made this contribution to ethics?:

- Ethics as a herd instinct
Friedrich Nietzche

Who made this contribution to ethics?:

- The ends justifies the means
Niccolo Machiavelli
The branch of philosophy that deals with the nature of beauty, art, taste, and the creation and appreciation of beauty.
Aesthetics
Why are aesthetics important?

1. It vitalizes our knowledge
2.It helps us to live more deeply and richly.
3.It brings us in touch with our culture.
4.It allows us to interpret messages.
What are the 3 great centers of philosophy?
China, Greece, India
This great center of philosophy is the oldest and deeply spiritual
India
This center of philosophy is focused on moral society and balance
China
This great center of philosophy is focused on reason, argument, and the quest for truth
Greece
In ancient times, did the west or east have more philosophical activites?
easet
This philosophy is linear in manner. Western or eastern?
Western
This philosophy is circular in manner. Western or eastern?
Eastern philosophy
In this type of philosophy, religion is separate. Western or eastern?
Western
In this philosophy, religion is synonymous with it. Western or eastern?
Eastern
This philosophy is more focused on individualism. Western or eastern?
Western
This philosophy is focused more on collectivism. Western or eastern?
Eastern
In this philosophy, the knower and the known are separated. Western or eastern?
Western
In this philosophy, the knower and the known unites.
Western or eastern?
What are the 3 dimensions of Filipino thought?

1. Loob
2. Filipino philosophy of time
3. "Bahala na"
This dimension of filipino thought includes Filipino virtues of the golden rule
Loob: Holistic and interior
When does loob:holistic and interior become negative?
if it becomes utang na loob
This dimension of filipino faith involves sharing oneself to others
loob:holistic and interior
Filipinos believe in "gulong ng palad" or wheel of fate. Which dimension of filipino thought is this?
Filipino philosophy of time
In the filipino philosophy of time, time is considered {{c1::cyclic}} with 2 parts which are {{c2::Biyaya}} and {{c2::Karma}}
In the filipino philosophy of time, {{c1::"siesta time"}} must not be viewed as negative.
Where is bathala from?
Southern tagalog

This phrase means to put complete trust in divine providence, believing that everything happens according to his will.

Clue: Tagalog
Bahala na
This diimension of filipino thought is seen as fatalistic
Bahala na

1.Abundance is not what we {{c2::gather}} but what
we {{c1::scatter}}.

2.Abundance is not what we {{c2::keep}} but what we
give {{c1::away}}.

3.Abundance is not what we {{c2::hold}} but what we
{{c1::share}}.
What are the steps for abundance?

1.Commit!

2.Be determined!

3.Persevere!

Philosophy helps us ask:

- For {{c2::whom}}? ({{c1::Ethos}})
- At what {{c2::cost}}? ({{c1::Pathos}})
- And {{c2::why}}? ({{c1::Logos)}}

Who said this, and what year:

“Epistemology is a science devoted to the discovery of the proper method of acquiring or validating knowledge”
Rand, 1990
What are the 2 main purposes of epistemology

1. Acquire knowledge
2. Validate knowledge
They said that we can acquire knowledge using our senses
Empiricists
They said that to think is to think of something; you cannot think about nothing
Rationalists
What are the 5 natures of knowledge in order?

1. Reality
2. Perception
3. Concept
4. Proposition
5. Inference

What we see, hear,
feel, taste, or smell
informs us about
the world. It is also
the most flawed part
of knowledge.

Which nature of knowledge is this?
Perception

"to know is to know something. existence is all there to know"

Which nature of knowledge is this?
Reality

For something to be known, it must first exist 

Which nature of knowledge is this?
Reality

Knowledge begins with perceptual knowledge. Stimulus through our senses

Which nature of knowledge is this?
Perception

“Abstractions from
abstractions.
Connecting
chunks of
knowledge.”

Which nature of knowledge is this?
Concept

Allows us to organize and categorize our experiences

Which nature of knowledge is this?
Concept

A declarative sentence.

Which nature of knowledge is this?
Proposition
A statement that affirms of denies something
Proposition
A statement that is capable of being true or false
Proposition

A reasoning process

Which nature of knowledge is this?
Inference
What are the two parts of an inference?
Premise and Conclusion
This part of an inference provides justification evidence and proof
Premise
This part of the inference is a staatement that we want to prove
Inference

Helps us distinguish true statements from false ones through structured reasoning
Logic

A logically valid argument leads from
premises to a conclusion in a way that?
if the premises are true, the conclusion must be true.
The art of reasoning that follows systematic processes
Logic
What are the 5 natures of truth in order?

1. Logic
2. Common Sense
3. Knowledge
4. Opinions
5. Arguments

It is a prudent, shallow judgment used to
validate whether if a thing is valid or not.
Common sense
Refers to practical, everyday reasoning that most people accept as sound without requiring deep analysis.
Common sense

A justified true belief — it must be
true, you must believe it, and you must have justification for believing it.
Knowledge
Personal beliefs, preferences, or judgments that may or may not be based on facts or logical reasoning.
Opinions
Tools used to arrive at or defend truth claims.
Arguments
A short but very deep book written by Ludwig Wittgenstein
Tractatus Logico-philosophicus
Who wrote Tractatus logico-philosophicus?
Ludwig Wittgenstein
This philosopher wanted to understand how language, thought, and reality all connect
Ludwig Wittgenstein
What is Ludwig Wittgenstein's famous quote?
"The world is all that is the case"
What does "the world is all that is the case" mean?
The world is made up of facts
"{{c2::Whereof one cannot speak}}, {{c1::thereof one must be silent}}."
According to Wittgenstein, what should we do when we encounter concepts that are too deep to describe using words?
Stay silent
According to Wittgenstein, what is philosophy's job?
To make thoughts clear
This is defined as a fact or reality that is objective and independent of anyone’s belief.
Truth
This theory states that a statement is true if it aligns with reality
Correspondence theory of truth

"There is a tree outside the window" This is true if there really is a tree outside the window. 


What theory of truth is this?
Correspondence theory of truth
This theory of truth states that a statement is true if it fits with a system of other truths
Coherence theory of truth
This theory of truth states that a statement is true if it works or is useful in real life.
Pragmatic theory of truth

"2 + 2 = 4" is true because it is consistent with the concepts of arithmetic

Which theory of truth is this?
Coherence theory of truth

"Washing hands prevents sickness" is true because it works and leads to healthy results

Which theory of truth is this?
Pragmatic theory of truth

What are the 4 natures of opinion? (BICO)

1. Based on emotion
2. Inherently biased
3. Cannot be confirmed
4. Open to interpretation

Opinions often come
from personal feelings
or preferences, not
from solid evidence or
reason.

Which nature of opinion is this?
Based on emotions

Since opinions are
subjective, different
people can interpret the
same situation or idea in
completely different ways.

Which nature of opinion is this?
Open to interpretation

Unlike facts or truths, opinions
cannot be definitively proven
using evidence or logic. They
may be supported, but never fully
confirmed in a universal sense.

which nature of truth is this?
Cannot be confirmed

Opinions carry the
backgrounds, and experiences of
the person who holds them.

Which nature of opinion is this?
Inherently biased
Why are humans complex? (4)
because they are capable of thinking,feeling, choosing, and seeking meaning.
This richness and depth of what it means to be human is what we refer to as the {{c1::complexity of man}}.
{{c1::Holism}} sees the human person as a complete, interconnected being — not just parts, but a living, unified whole.
In holism, to truly understand something, you must look at the {{c1::entire system}}, not just {{c1::its individual piece.}}
“The whole is greater than the sum of its parts."
Holism
“A complex thing can be fully understood by breaking it down into its simplest parts.
Reductionism
In reductionism, to truly understand something, we must analyze its {{c1::smaller, basic components.}}
It's good for analyzing specific details, but not always enough to understand the whole reality.
Reductionism
This refers to humankind
Man
This refers to member of Homo sapiens
Human
This refers to a being with dignity, reason, freedom, and rights
Human Person
What are the three components that makes up a human person?
Mind + Body + Spirit
The {{c1::Cognitive Self}} refers to how we understand, process, and think about ourselves and the world around us.
It is the part of the self that involves thinking, reasoning, remembering, analyzing, and reflecting.
Cognitive self
It involves self-awareness/existence, memory, self-reflection, and decision-making
Cognitive self
The {{c1::Physical Self}} refers to a person’s body — including their appearance, biological makeup, health, and physical capabilities.
It is the most visible and tangible aspect of the human person.
Physical Self
Its features include: body and physical appearance, health and hygiene, senses, growth and body development
Physical Self
The {{c1::Spiritual Self}} refers to the part of the human person that seeks purpose, meaning, inner peace, and connection — either with a higher power, a greater truth, or one’s deepest values.
It’s about your inner life, your sense of direction, and your search for meaning beyond material things.
Spiritual Self
Spritual self is limited to religion, T or F?
F
This includes meaning and purpose, belief system, values and principles, morality and transcendence
Spiritual Self
To transcend means to {{c1::go beyond}}
{{c1::Transcendence}} means to rise above physical, emotional, mental, or spiritual limitations in order to reach a higher state of understanding, being, or purpose.
In philosophy, what does transcendence refer to? (3)

the human capacity to go:
(1) beyond the self;
(2) beyond the material world and;
(3) toward truth, goodness, beauty, or the divine.
What are the three limits to transcendence?

1. Biological/ Physical Limits
2. Psychological Limits
3. Moral & Spiritual Limits
What are the biological/physical limits to transcendence? (3)

• We get tired, sick, hungry, and we die.
  • Our senses are limited
  • The body can weigh down the spirit when it is overburdened.
What are psychological/emotional limits to transcendence? (2)

• Fears, traumas, doubts, or lack of confidence
  • emotional pain
What are moral and spiritual limits to transcendence? (2)

• Selfishness, hatred, greed, and pride 
  • When we turn away from what is true or good
When we turn away from what is true or good, we become {{c1::trapped in the self.}}
People may stop dreaming or hoping due to {{c1::emotional pain.}}
The body can weigh down the spirit when it is {{c1::overburdened.}}
What kind of limit is being showed? Illness preventing someone from pursuing their calling.
Biological/Physical Limits
What kind of limit is this: A student with great potential who gives up due to low self-esteem.
Psychological/Emotional Limits
What kind of limit is this: Someone pursuing wealth at the cost of relationships and meaning.
Moral and Spiritual Limits
What are the 6 possibilities to transcendence?

1. Forgiveness
2. Beauty of Nature
3. Vulnerability
4. Failure
5. Loneliness
6. Love
When we forgive, we are freed from our {{c1::anger}} and {{c1::bitterness.}}
Experiencing the nature can be truly {{c1::moments of grace}}  where human hearts are {{c1::lifted}}.
To be {{c1::vulnerable}} is to be {{c2::human}}
Without seeking help from others is to live {{c1::without direction}}
{{c1::Failure}} forces us confront our weaknesses and limitations.
Acceptance of failure makes us {{c2::hope}} and {{c1::trust.}}
With {{c1::solitude}}, we realize that dependence is a possessiveness that we can be free from.
To {{c1::love}} is to experience {{c2::richness}}
The goal of this philsophizing method is to achieve deeper understanding through rational discourse and contradiction.
Dialectic Method
It uses questions to expose contradictions in one’s beliefs and refine understanding.
Socratic Method
A dialogue between individuals where they ask and answer questions to arrive at the truth.
Socratic Method
Who created the Thesis & Antithesis?
George Wilhelm Friedrich Hegel
In Hegel’s dialectic, {{c1::thesis}} is an initial idea or position, and {{c1::antithesis}} is its direct opposite or contradiction.
The conflict between theses and antitheses is leads to a {{c1::synthesis}}
Three components of George Hegel's dialectic method

1) Thesis
2) Antithesis
3) Synthesis
The goal of this method of philosophizing is to evaluate ideas based on their effectiveness and results in practical situations.
Pragmatic Method
In pragmatic method, philosophy must be {{c1::practical}} and {{c1::useful}}.
Who said this "An idea is true if it works or has practical consequences in real life"
John Dewey
This method of philosophizing aims to discover the essence of experiences by examining people from a first-person point of view.
Phenomenological Method
This philosophizing method focuses on lived experience and consciousness.
Phenomenological Method
Suspending or “bracketing” assumptions about reality to examine how things appear to consciousness.
Epoché
Whose method of philosophizing is focused on lived experience and consciousness?
Edmund Husserl
The goal of phenomenological method is to {{c1::describe}} experiences, not to {{c1::explain}} or {{c1::analyze}} them.
The goal is to move from analysis (primary) to deeper understanding (secondary) of self and others.
Primary and Secondary Reflections
In primary and secondary reflections, you move from {{c1::analysis (primary)}} to {{c1::deeper understanding (secondary)}} of self and others.
Who coined primary and secondary reflections?
Gabriel Marcel
This method of philosophizing is used to understand human existence, love, faith, and suffering.
Primary and Secondary Reflections
This reflection breaks things down to analyze, categorize, and problem-solve (objective thinking).
Primary Reflection
This reflection reintegrates the experience to grasp its meaning and unity (subjective and existential thinking).
Secondary Reflection
The goal of this philosophizing method is to eliminate confusion in philosophical problems by analyzing language and its logic.
Analytic Method
What did Ludwig Wittgenstein say about the existence of philosophical problems?
Philosophical problems exist because of the misuse of language.
What is the job of philosophy according to Wittgenstein?
to make thoughts clear
Which philosopher emphasized clarity in language and logic?
Ludwig Wittgenstein
The {{c1::Embodied Spirit}} refers to the understanding of the human person as both body and soul, unified as one being.
This concept is central in philosophy and theology that emphasizes that we are not merely physical bodies nor purely spiritual entities—we are {{c1::embodied spirits}}
What is the relationship between body and soul according to the concept of the embodied spirit?
The body is not a shell trapping the soul; the soul expresses itself through the body.
How do we experience and interact with the world in the embodied spirit view?
We experience the world through our body, and reflect, love, create, and hope through the spirit.
What defines a human person according to the embodied spirit concept?
The integration of body and spirit is what makes us truly human.
According to Christianity, what is the nature of the human person?
The human person is a unity of body and spirit, made in the image and likeness of God.
In Christianity, the {{c2::soul}} is {{c1::immortal}}, while the {{c2::body}} is {{c1::temporal}}.
Upon death, the soul {{c1::lives on,}} and Christians believe in the {{c1::resurrection}} of the body at the end of time.
What are two key implications about the body in Christianity?

1. The body is sacred; it should be respected
2. Our actions in the body affect the soul (e.g., making sins)
In Christianity, the body is {{c1::sacred}}; it should be {{c1::respected}}
What concept expresses transcendence in Christianity?
Will and Love  or “Do good and avoid evil”
Which saint/s said the concept of transcendence in Christianity is “Do good and avoid evil”?
St. Augustine and St. Thomas Aquinas
How does Hinduism view the body and soul?
The body is temporary; the ātman (eternal soul) is immortal and divine, part of Brahman (Ultimate Reality).
In Hinduism, the body is {{c1::temporary}}; the {{c1::ātman (eternal soul)}} is immortal and divine, part of {{c1::Brahman (Ultimate Reality)}}.
What does atman refer to in Hinduism?
eternal soul
What is Brahman in Hinduism?
ultimate reality
What is the cycle of reincarnation in Hinduism called?
samsāra
{{c1::Liberation or moksha}} is the release of the soul from the cycle of rebirth, reuniting it with Brahman.
What are the two implication in Hinduism?

1. The embodied life is a phase in spiritual evolution
2. living virtuously helps purify the soul.
What concepts explain transcendence in Hinduism?
Reincarnation (Metempsychosis) and Karma.
In Hinduism, these are the central beliefs that explain how life, actions, and the soul are connected across lifetimes
Reincarnation aka “Metempsychosis” and Karma
What is Buddhism’s view on the soul?
Buddhism rejects an eternal soul (ātman) and teaches anattā (non-self), a continuous process of consciousness.
What is anatta in buddhism?
non-self
What is the five aggregates of the human person in Buddhism?

1) form
2) sensation
3) perception
4) mental formations
5) consciousness
What are implications of Buddhism’s view on body and mind?
While the body and mind are impermanent, ethical living and meditation help liberate one from illusion and suffering.
What is the goal of rebirth and existence in Buddhism?
To achieve nirvana, freedom from suffering and rebirth.
The state in which one is absolutely free from all forms of bondage and attachment
Nirvana
What is transcendence in Buddhism?
Nirvana — the state free from all bondage and attachment.
What is Plato’s view on the body and soul?
Dualism
The soul is the true essence of a person, while the body is a temporary prison.
Dualism
What is Aristotle’s view on the soul and body?
Hylomorphism
How does St. Augustine describe the embodied spirit?
CHRISTIAN DUALISM
What is St. Thomas Aquinas’s perspective on the embodied spirit?
Christian Hylomorphism
What does René Descartes say about mind and body?
Cartesian Dualism
How does Gabriel Marcel view the embodied spirit?
Existential Holism
The soul is the true essence of a person, and the body is a temporary prison hindering the soul’s pursuit of truth.
Dualism
Who believed that “The body is mortal; the soul is immortal."?
Plato
According to Plato, real knowledge comes through the soul’s recollection of the {{c1::world of forms (ideal realities)}}.
The soul is the form of the body, meaning the soul cannot exist without the body.
Aristotle’s Hylomorphism
In hylomorphism, the person is a {{c1::composite being}}; body and soul are {{c1::one substance}}.
Who believed that “Man is a rational being"?
Aristotle
The soul is superior to the body but both are created by God.
Christian Dualism
According to Christian Dualism, the human person is a unity of {{c1::body and soul}}, destined for union with {{c1::God}}.
Who said this: "You have made us for Yourself, O Lord, and our heart is restless until it rests in You."
St. Augustine
The soul is the form of the body, but both are necessary for full human existence.
Christian Hylomorphism
In which idea of embodied does this apply: Human beings are rational, embodied souls— created in God’s image.
Christian Hylomorphism
Who said :The soul is united to the body as its form. "?
St. Thomas Aquinas
In Cartesian Dualism, the {{c1::mind}} {{c2::(res cogitans)}} and {{c1::body}} {{c2::(res extensa)}} are two distinct substances.
On which perspective of embodied spirit does this apply: The self is essentially a thinking thing; the body is separate and less important.
Cartesian Dualism
Who quoted "Cogito, ergo sum"?
RENÉ DESCARTES
What does "Cogito, ergo sum" mean?
"I think, therefore I am"
Opposed to objectifying the body; you don’t have a body—you are a body.
Existential Holism
In existential holism, the person is a {{c1::mystery}}—body and spirit intimately united. He emphasizes {{c1::“I”}}
Which philosopher said “I am my body.”?
Gabriel Marcel
This concept focuses on the appreciation, evaluation, and experience of the environment through an aesthetic lens
Environmental Aesthetics
What are the 4 purposes of environmental aesthetics (ACQE)

- Awareness
- Conservation
- Quality of life
- Ethics
Which purpose of environmental aesthetics is this? Aesthetic appreciation fosters deeper connection with nature
Awareness
Which purpose of environmental aesthetics is this? People are more likely to protect what they find beautiful and meaningful
Conservation
Which purpose of environmental aesthetics is this? Beautiful environments improve mental health, reduce stress, and inspire creativity
Quality of life
Which purpose of environmental aesthetics is this? Beauty is linked with moral responsibility -- destroying a beautiful place is seen as a moral loss.
